The plaintiffs said these actions were an unreasonable seizure and excessive force, violating their rights under the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments. They also claimed the defendants discriminated against them because of their disabilities and didn't provide reasonable accommodations.

On September 9, 2015, the defendants filed a joint request to dismiss the case, arguing the lawsuit didn't state a valid legal claim. On September 30, 2015, the plaintiffs filed their own request for judgment based on the legal arguments presented.

On December 28, 2015, Judge William O. Bertelsman denied the defendants' request to dismiss the case. The Court found that the plaintiffs had presented enough facts to support a claim of constitutional violation under § 1983. The plaintiffs also presented enough facts to support believable claims of discrimination under Title II.

In October 2016, both sides asked the court for a partial summary judgment, meaning a ruling on some parts of the case without a full trial. Additionally, on September 14, 2017, the defendants filed a request to separate the two students' claims. Judge Bertelsman denied this request because the two handcuffing incidents were very similar, and they shared a key legal question: whether elbow-cuffing these children was against the law.

On October 11, 2017, Judge Bertelsman ruled on the parties' requests for partial summary judgment. Judge Bertelsman sided with the plaintiffs on their claims that the handcuffing was an unlawful seizure and excessive force, and that Kenton County was responsible for these violations. The Court considered several legal factors and found that even though the seriousness of the alleged crime favored the defendants, other factors favored the plaintiffs, such as whether the children were an immediate threat, their age and size, and how they were handcuffed.

However, Judge Bertelsman ruled against the plaintiffs on their ADA discrimination and reasonable accommodation claims. The Court found that no reasonable jury could conclude that the defendants handcuffed the plaintiffs *because of* their disabilities, rather than because of their behavior on those specific days.

Additionally, Judge Bertelsman sided with the defendants on the issue of "qualified immunity," which protects government officials from certain lawsuits. Although the Court said it was a difficult decision, it found that the plaintiffs couldn't show that it was already clearly established in law that this type of handcuffing was unconstitutional. The Court found that the Supreme Court cases the plaintiffs cited were too general and that the plaintiffs didn't point to any specific rulings from the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals.

On February 7, 2018, the defendants (in their official roles) asked to dismiss the plaintiffs' constitutional claims under § 1983, arguing the court lacked the authority to hear them due to "state sovereign immunity," a protection for states from certain lawsuits, under the Eleventh Amendment. Before a hearing on damages, the Court said it would consider the defendants' request to dismiss.

However, after a meeting to discuss a settlement on April 13, 2018, the parties privately agreed that the defendants would pay over $337,000 in damages. The Court closed the case permanently on November 1, 2018, ordering each side to pay their own legal costs.

3.transformed_text:
On August 3, 2015, two students with disabilities sued in federal court in Kentucky. These students sued the local Sheriff's Office, the Sheriff himself (acting in his job), and a School Resource Officer (both in his job and as an individual). They claimed their rights were violated under a federal law that protects people's civil rights, and also under a disability rights law called the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). The students, with help from groups like the ACLU and private lawyers, asked the court to make the Sheriff's Office stop these actions, officially state that their rights were violated, and pay them money for the harm they suffered. They said the defendants used too much physical force and handcuffs on students, especially those with disabilities. The students argued this was like an illegal arrest and too much force, meaning the police held them unfairly and used more force than necessary. This, they argued, went against their rights under the U.S. Constitution, which protects people from such actions. They also claimed they were treated unfairly because of their disabilities and weren't given the help or changes they needed (what lawyers call 'reasonable accommodations').

A month later, on September 9, 2015, the Sheriff's Office and the other defendants asked the judge to throw out the case, saying the lawsuit didn't have enough facts to prove a legal problem. Soon after, on September 30, 2015, the students filed their own request, asking the judge to rule in their favor just based on the written arguments, without a full trial.

On December 28, 2015, Judge William O. Bertelsman said 'no' to the defendants' request to dismiss the case. The judge decided the students had shared enough information to show that their constitutional rights might have been violated under that federal civil rights law. And, they had enough facts to make believable claims of discrimination under the ADA.

In October 2016, both sides asked the judge to make a decision on *some* parts of the case without going through a whole trial. Also, in September 2017, the defendants asked to separate the cases of the two students, treating them as completely different lawsuits. But Judge Bertelsman said no. He explained that both handcuffing incidents were very similar and raised the same big question: was putting elbow-cuffs on these children against the law?

On October 11, 2017, Judge Bertelsman made his decision on those requests for partial judgment. He sided with the students, agreeing that the handcuffing was an illegal arrest and used too much force. He also said that Kenton County, as a government body, was responsible for these actions. The court looked at several important factors. For example, while the seriousness of what the students were accused of might have helped the defendants' argument, other key things favored the students: like whether they were an immediate danger to anyone, their age and size, and *how* they were handcuffed.

But, Judge Bertelsman ruled against the students on their claims that they were discriminated against because of their disabilities or weren't given reasonable accommodations. The judge felt that no fair jury would conclude that the defendants handcuffed the children *because* they had disabilities. Instead, he believed it was because of how the children behaved on those particular days.

Also, Judge Bertelsman sided with the defendants on something called 'qualified immunity.' Think of this as a special shield that protects government officials from certain lawsuits, unless their actions clearly violated a well-known law. Even though the judge said it was a tough call, he found that the students couldn't prove that the law was already *so clear* that this specific way of handcuffing was definitely against the Constitution. He explained that the Supreme Court cases the students relied on were too general. They didn't point to any specific rulings from the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals, which is the higher court that oversees Kentucky and its legal decisions.

On February 7, 2018, the defendants (acting in their official jobs) again asked the court to dismiss the students' claims about their constitutional rights. They argued the court couldn't even hear these claims because of something called 'state sovereign immunity.' This is like a rule from the Constitution's Eleventh Amendment that says states are protected from certain lawsuits. Before a hearing to decide how much money the students should receive, the judge said he would consider the defendants' request to dismiss.

However, after a meeting to try and settle the case on April 13, 2018, both sides privately agreed that the defendants would pay the students over $337,000 to resolve the case. The court officially closed the case for good on November 1, 2018, with each side responsible for paying their own legal costs.

1.transformed_text:
In August 2015, a significant legal battle began when two minor children with disabilities sought justice in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Kentucky. They initiated a lawsuit against the Kenton County Sheriff's Office, the Sheriff, and a School Resource Officer, driven by claims that they had endured unnecessary and excessive physical restraint, including handcuffing, at school. Their core argument was that these actions violated their Fourth and Fourteenth Amendment rights through unreasonable seizure and excessive force, and constituted discrimination under the Americans with Disabilities Act. Through this legal challenge, the children, supported by the ACLU, aimed to secure injunctive relief, declaratory relief, and damages, hoping to halt such practices and gain recompense for their experiences.

The defendants quickly responded in September 2015 by filing a motion to dismiss the case. Their strategic objective was to end the lawsuit at its earliest stage, arguing that even if the plaintiffs' allegations were true, they did not amount to legally recognizable claims. In response, the plaintiffs filed their own cross motion, seeking an early judgment in their favor, believing the pleadings alone demonstrated their entitlement to relief.

However, in December 2015, Judge William O. Bertelsman denied the defendants' attempt to dismiss the case. The Court found that the children had indeed presented a plausible narrative of constitutional violations and discrimination, allowing their claims to proceed and requiring the defendants to answer the allegations more fully.

As the case matured, both sides sought to resolve parts of the dispute without a full trial. In October 2016, they filed cross motions for partial summary judgment, each hoping to secure a definitive ruling on certain claims based on the evidence gathered. The defendants also attempted, in September 2017, to sever the claims of the two students, likely hoping to treat their experiences as isolated incidents rather than a pattern. Yet, Judge Bertelsman denied this motion, recognizing the substantial factual similarities between the two handcuffing situations and the common legal question of whether such "elbow-cuffing" was unconstitutional, thus keeping the plaintiffs' unified narrative intact.

In October 2017, Judge Bertelsman delivered a significant ruling on the summary judgment motions. He sided with the plaintiffs on their core claims of unlawful seizure and excessive force, holding Kenton County liable for these constitutional violations. The judge's analysis, applying established legal factors, found that despite the severity of the children's initial behavior, their age, stature, and the method of handcuffing strongly supported the plaintiffs' case. However, the judge ruled against the plaintiffs on their ADA discrimination claims, concluding that the handcuffing was more likely a response to their behavior than a direct result of their disabilities. Furthermore, the judge granted qualified immunity to the individual officer, determining that while the handcuffing was unconstitutional, it was not *clearly established* as such by prior legal precedent at the time, thus shielding the officer from personal liability.

Despite these partial rulings, the defendants made another attempt in February 2018 to dismiss the constitutional claims, asserting state sovereign immunity to avoid paying damages. This final procedural challenge aimed to prevent any financial award.

Ultimately, the parties chose to resolve the long-running dispute through negotiation. Following a settlement conference in April 2018, they reached a private agreement where the defendants consented to pay over $337,000 in damages. This settlement, which led to the case's dismissal in November 2018, brought a definitive end to the legal struggle, providing the plaintiffs with substantial compensation and concluding a notable chapter in the history of disability rights and law enforcement practices in schools.

original_case_data.name: Foote v. Ludlow School Committee
original_case_data.plaintiff_description: Two sets of parents whose children attend Ludlow school district.
original_case_data.summary:
This case involved four parents who believed local public school officials overreached when they chose not to disclose their children’s decision to establish a new gender identity at school. On April 12, 2022, two sets of parents filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts. The parents sued the school district and various officials, administrators, and teachers in their official capacity under 42 U.S.C. 1983. Represented by public interest attorneys for the Massachusetts Family Institute and Child and Parental Rights Campaign, the parents sought various declarations regarding the policy at issue to be unconstitutional, an injunction against adherence to the policy, nominal damages, compensatory damages, and attorneys’ fees.

Plaintiffs claimed that a school district may not empower individual teachers to assist students who are in the midst of a crisis of gender identity to transition and in particular to conceal in any manner the student's desire to transition or feelings on the matter from the parents either deliberately or accidentally. In 2012, the Massachusetts Board of Elementary and Secondary Education published guidance for school districts when faced with the instant issue. While the guidance has never been adopted as legally binding or as such to have substantive effect, the plaintiffs rely on the Board’s suggestion for how individual school districts should handle informing parents of their children’s gender identity crisis. The plaintiffs argued that in the absence of a local school district policy to the contrary, the Board’s guidance should govern.

On July 29, 2022, Defendants filed a motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim. Defendants argued that plaintiffs lacked Article III standing because they failed to allege that their children were transgender or had interacted with any of the defendants, failing both the cause or controversy requirement, traceability, and claim upon which relief could be granted requirements of standing. Defendants also asserted qualified immunity.

District Judge Mark Mastroianni granted Defendant’s motion to dismiss for lack of standing on December 14, 2022, and noted that in the alternative the allegations in the complaint would not have overcome the school district’s qualified immunity. 2022 WL 18356421. On January 11, 2023, Plaintiffs appealed the dismissal to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. 

On February 18, 2025, the appellate court upheld the dismissal, concluding that the plaintiffs failed to present a plausible claim that the school's protocol infringed upon their fundamental right under the due process clause “to direct the upbringing of their child.” 

On February 18, 2025, the appellate court upheld the dismissal, concluding that the plaintiffs failed to present a plausible claim that the school's protocol infringed upon their fundamental right under the due process clause “to direct the upbringing of their child.” The court also noted that the “shock-in-conscience” test was not the appropriate legal standard to utilize because the school policy was not executive but legislative conduct. The court based this conclusion on the fact that the policy applies broadly to all students and is administered by multiple government actors. Thus, the test they used was whether the plaintiffs had adequately alleged that Ludlow’s conduct restricted a fundamental right, which the court concluded it had not. 

As of February 19, 2025, the case is ongoing.
original_case_data.summary_short: This case involved four parents who believed local public school officials overreached when they chose not to disclose their minor childrens’ decision to establish a new gender identity at school. On April 12, 2022, two sets of parents filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts. The parents sued the school district and various officials, administrators, and teachers in their official capacity under 42 U.S.C. 1983. District Judge Mark Mastroianni granted the defendant’s 12(b)(6) motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim based upon substantive grounds, but that in the alternative the allegations in the complaint would not have overcome the school district’s qualified immunity. The parents appealed to the First Circuit, which affirmed the district court's dismissal on February 18, 2025.

2.transformed_text:
This case involved four parents who alleged local public school officials overreached by not disclosing their children’s decision to establish a new gender identity at school. On April 12, 2022, two sets of parents, represented by public interest attorneys, initiated an action in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts. They sued the school district and various officials, administrators, and teachers in their official capacity under 42 U.S.C. 1983, seeking declarations that the policy was unconstitutional, an injunction against its adherence, nominal and compensatory damages, and attorneys’ fees.

Plaintiffs contended that a school district may not empower teachers to assist students with gender identity transitions or to conceal such matters from parents, whether deliberately or accidentally. They relied on 2012 Massachusetts Board of Elementary and Secondary Education guidance, arguing it should govern in the absence of a contrary local policy, despite its non-binding status.

Defendants moved to dismiss the complaint for failure to state a claim. They asserted plaintiffs lacked Article III standing, arguing they failed to allege their children were transgender or had interacted with defendants, thus failing the cause or controversy, traceability, and relief requirements. Defendants also invoked qualified immunity.

On December 14, 2022, District Judge Mark Mastroianni granted the defendants’ motion to dismiss for lack of standing. The court alternatively noted that the complaint's allegations would not have overcome the school district’s qualified immunity. Plaintiffs appealed the dismissal to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the First Circuit.

On February 18, 2025, the appellate court affirmed the dismissal. The court concluded that plaintiffs failed to present a plausible claim that the school's protocol infringed upon their fundamental due process right “to direct the upbringing of their child.” The court further determined that the “shock-in-conscience” test was inapplicable because the school policy constituted legislative, not executive, conduct, given its broad application to all students and administration by multiple government actors. Consequently, the court assessed whether plaintiffs adequately alleged Ludlow’s conduct restricted a fundamental right, concluding they had not. The case remains ongoing as of February 19, 2025.

3.transformed_text:
**Executive Summary**

The U.S. Court of Appeals for the First Circuit affirmed the dismissal of a lawsuit initiated by parents challenging a local public school district's policy concerning students' gender identity transitions without parental notification, concluding that the policy did not infringe upon fundamental parental due process rights.

*   Four parents filed suit under 42 U.S.C. 1983 against a school district and officials in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts, alleging overreach for not disclosing their children’s decision to establish a new gender identity at school and seeking declarations of unconstitutionality, an injunction, and damages.
*   Defendants moved to dismiss for failure to state a claim, asserting plaintiffs lacked Article III standing due to insufficient allegations regarding their children's transgender status or interaction with defendants, and invoking qualified immunity.
*   The District Court granted the motion to dismiss, primarily for lack of standing, and alternatively noted that the complaint's allegations would not have overcome the school district’s qualified immunity.
*   On appeal, the First Circuit affirmed the dismissal, concluding that plaintiffs failed to plausibly claim the school's protocol infringed their fundamental due process right "to direct the upbringing of their child." The court also determined the "shock-in-conscience" test was inapplicable because the school policy constituted legislative, not executive, conduct, assessing instead whether a fundamental right was restricted, which it concluded was not adequately alleged.

1.transformed_text:
This case involved four parents who believed local public school officials went too far by not telling them that their children had decided to identify as a different gender at school. On April 12, 2022, two sets of parents sued in federal court in Massachusetts. The parents sued the school district and several officials, administrators, and teachers in their roles as school employees, under a federal civil rights law. They were represented by public interest lawyers from the Massachusetts Family Institute and Child and Parental Rights Campaign. The parents asked the court to declare the school's policy unconstitutional, order the school to stop following it, and award them small damages, money for their losses, and legal fees.

The parents argued that a school district should not allow teachers to help students exploring their gender identity and possibly transitioning, especially by hiding a student's desire to transition or feelings about it from their parents, whether on purpose or by accident. In 2012, the Massachusetts Board of Elementary and Secondary Education released guidelines for schools dealing with this issue. Even though these guidelines were never made legally binding or given real legal power, the parents relied on the Board's suggestion for how schools should tell parents about their children's gender identity exploration. They argued that if a local school district didn't have its own policy, the Board's guidelines should apply.

On July 29, 2022, the school officials asked the court to throw out the case, arguing that the lawsuit didn't state a valid legal claim. The school officials argued that the parents didn't have the legal right to sue in federal court. They said the parents hadn't claimed that their children were transgender or had even interacted with any of the specific school employees named in the lawsuit. This meant the parents didn't meet the rules for who can sue, including showing a real dispute and that the school caused their harm. The school officials also claimed "qualified immunity," a legal protection for government officials.

On December 14, 2022, District Judge Mark Mastroianni agreed with the school officials and dismissed the case because the parents lacked the legal right to sue. He also noted that even if the standing issue wasn't there, what the parents claimed in their lawsuit wouldn't have been enough to get past the school district's qualified immunity protection. 2022 WL 18356421. On January 11, 2023, the parents appealed this dismissal to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the First Circuit.

On February 18, 2025, the appeals court agreed with the dismissal. It found that the parents failed to make a believable legal argument that the school's policy violated their basic right, protected by the Constitution's "due process" clause, to "direct the upbringing of their child."

The court also said that the "shock-the-conscience" test was not the right legal test to use. This was because the school policy was a general rule-making action (legislative), not a specific decision by an official (executive). The court concluded this because the policy applies broadly to all students and is handled by many school employees. So, the test they used was whether the parents had sufficiently claimed that Ludlow's actions limited a basic right, which the court decided they had not.

As of February 19, 2025, the case is still ongoing.

On April 12, 2022, two sets of parents sued in federal court in Massachusetts. The parents sued the school district and its staff – officials, administrators, and teachers. They sued them in their roles as school employees, using a federal civil rights law. They were represented by public interest lawyers from the Massachusetts Family Institute and Child and Parental Rights Campaign. The parents asked the court to rule the school's policy was unconstitutional. They wanted the court to order the school to stop using it. They also sought small damages, money for their losses, and legal fees.

The parents argued schools should not let teachers help students explore their gender identity or transition. They especially felt teachers should not hide a student's desire to transition or feelings about it from parents, whether on purpose or by accident. In 2012, the Massachusetts Board of Elementary and Secondary Education released guidelines for schools dealing with this issue. These guidelines were never legally binding or given real power. Still, the parents relied on the Board's suggestion for how schools should tell parents about their children's gender identity exploration. They argued that if a local school district didn't have its own policy, the Board's guidelines should apply.

On July 29, 2022, school officials asked the court to throw out the case. They argued the lawsuit didn't state a valid legal claim. The school officials argued that the parents didn't have the legal right to sue in federal court. They said the parents hadn't claimed their children were transgender. Also, they hadn't claimed their children interacted with any specific school employees named in the lawsuit. This meant the parents didn't meet the rules for who can sue. These rules include showing a real dispute and that the school caused their harm. The school officials also claimed "qualified immunity," a legal protection for government officials.

On December 14, 2022, District Judge Mark Mastroianni agreed with the school officials. He dismissed the case because the parents lacked the legal right to sue. He also noted that even if the parents had the right to sue, their claims in the lawsuit would not have been enough. They wouldn't have overcome the school district's qualified immunity protection. On January 11, 2023, the parents appealed this dismissal to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the First Circuit.

On February 18, 2025, the appeals court agreed with the dismissal. It found the parents failed to make a believable legal argument. They said the school's policy violated their basic right to "direct the upbringing of their child." This right is protected by the Constitution's "due process" clause.

The court also said the "shock-the-conscience" test was not the right legal test to use. This was because the school policy was a general rule-making action, like a law (legislative). It was not a specific decision by an official (executive). The court reached this conclusion because the policy applies broadly to all students. Many school employees handle it. So, the test they used was whether the parents had sufficiently claimed that Ludlow's actions limited a basic right. The court decided they had not.

As of February 19, 2025, the case is still ongoing.

0.text:
This case involved four parents who believed local public school officials overreached when they chose not to disclose their children’s decision to establish a new gender identity at school. On April 12, 2022, two sets of parents filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts. The parents sued the school district and various officials, administrators, and teachers in their official capacity under 42 U.S.C. 1983. Represented by public interest attorneys for the Massachusetts Family Institute and Child and Parental Rights Campaign, the parents sought various declarations regarding the policy at issue to be unconstitutional, an injunction against adherence to the policy, nominal damages, compensatory damages, and attorneys’ fees.

Plaintiffs claimed that a school district may not empower individual teachers to assist students who are in the midst of a crisis of gender identity to transition and in particular to conceal in any manner the student's desire to transition or feelings on the matter from the parents either deliberately or accidentally. In 2012, the Massachusetts Board of Elementary and Secondary Education published guidance for school districts when faced with the instant issue. While the guidance has never been adopted as legally binding or as such to have substantive effect, the plaintiffs rely on the Board’s suggestion for how individual school districts should handle informing parents of their children’s gender identity crisis. The plaintiffs argued that in the absence of a local school district policy to the contrary, the Board’s guidance should govern.

On July 29, 2022, Defendants filed a motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim. Defendants argued that plaintiffs lacked Article III standing because they failed to allege that their children were transgender or had interacted with any of the defendants, failing both the cause or controversy requirement, traceability, and claim upon which relief could be granted requirements of standing. Defendants also asserted qualified immunity.

District Judge Mark Mastroianni granted Defendant’s motion to dismiss for lack of standing on December 14, 2022, and noted that in the alternative the allegations in the complaint would not have overcome the school district’s qualified immunity. 2022 WL 18356421. On January 11, 2023, Plaintiffs appealed the dismissal to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. 

On February 18, 2025, the appellate court upheld the dismissal, concluding that the plaintiffs failed to present a plausible claim that the school's protocol infringed upon their fundamental right under the due process clause “to direct the upbringing of their child.” 

On February 18, 2025, the appellate court upheld the dismissal, concluding that the plaintiffs failed to present a plausible claim that the school's protocol infringed upon their fundamental right under the due process clause “to direct the upbringing of their child.” The court also noted that the “shock-in-conscience” test was not the appropriate legal standard to utilize because the school policy was not executive but legislative conduct. The court based this conclusion on the fact that the policy applies broadly to all students and is administered by multiple government actors. Thus, the test they used was whether the plaintiffs had adequately alleged that Ludlow’s conduct restricted a fundamental right, which the court concluded it had not. 

As of February 19, 2025, the case is ongoing.

1.transformed_text:
This historical account begins with four parents who harbored a profound concern: they believed local public school officials had overstepped their authority by choosing not to inform them when their children decided to embrace a new gender identity at school. Driven by this conviction and a desire to assert their parental rights, two sets of these parents initiated legal action on April 12, 2022, in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts. Their lawsuit, supported by public interest attorneys, was a direct challenge to the school district and its officials, seeking not only declarations that the school's policy was unconstitutional but also an injunction to halt its practice, along with damages and legal fees.

At the heart of the parents' grievance was their contention that school districts should not empower individual teachers to facilitate a student's gender transition or, crucially, to conceal such developments from parents. They pointed to 2012 guidance from the Massachusetts Board of Elementary and Secondary Education, which, though not legally binding, suggested how schools *should* handle informing parents about a child's gender identity crisis. The parents argued that, absent a local policy, this state guidance should have been followed, reflecting their expectation of transparency and involvement in their children's lives.

However, the school district and its officials sought to quickly end the legal challenge. On July 29, 2022, they filed a motion to dismiss, strategically arguing that the parents lacked the necessary "standing" to bring their case in federal court. This procedural move aimed to demonstrate that the parents had not sufficiently shown a direct personal injury or connection to the alleged wrongdoing, or that their children were even directly affected, which are prerequisites for a federal lawsuit. They also claimed "qualified immunity," a defense intended to shield public officials from liability for actions taken in their official capacity.

The District Judge, Mark Mastroianni, sided with the school officials on December 14, 2022, agreeing that the parents had not established the required standing to proceed with their claims. He also noted that, even if they had, their allegations likely wouldn't have overcome the school district's immunity. Undeterred, the parents continued their pursuit of justice, appealing the dismissal to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the First Circuit on January 11, 2023.

Yet, on February 18, 2025, the appellate court affirmed the lower court's decision. The court concluded that the parents had failed to plausibly demonstrate that the school's protocol infringed upon their fundamental constitutional right "to direct the upbringing of their child." In essence, the court determined that the school's broad policy, applying to all students, did not constitute a direct enough governmental intrusion on parental rights to warrant judicial intervention under the specific legal standard applied.

As of February 19, 2025, this legal narrative continues to unfold.

original_case_data.name: Alicia B. v. Malloy
original_case_data.plaintiff_description: Children sent to an alternative educational program after being expelled from public school.
settlement_agreement: Court Approved Settlement or Consent Decree
original_case_data.summary:
On December 15, 2015, two African-American students in Connecticut public schools filed this lawsuit in Connecticut Superior Court. On January 14, 2016, the case was removed to the United States District Court for the District of Connecticut. The plaintiffs sued the Bloomfield Board of Education, the Manchester Board of Education, the Hartford Board of Education, the State Board of Education, and the State Department of Education under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 and Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, alleging violations of the Constitution of Connecticut, the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, and Title VI.

Specifically, the plaintiffs claimed that, after their expulsion from Connecticut public schools, they were given inadequate alternative education, thus depriving them of their fundamental right to an education. They argued that Black students were particularly affected by these inadequacies because Black students were disproportionately expelled as a result of selective enforcement of neutral discipline policies. One plaintiff brought claims against the Manchester and Bloomfield Boards of Education. Both plaintiffs brought claims against the Hartford Board of Education. The plaintiffs, represented by private counsel and the Center for Children’s Advocacy, asked the court for declaratory and injunctive relief to improve the insufficient education provided to students who had been expelled. The plaintiffs also requested reasonable attorneys' fees and costs.

On August 11, 2016, Manchester Board of Education defendants settled with one of the plaintiffs. This settlement is sealed.

On August 16, 2016, the Bloomfield Board of Education also settled with the same plaintiff. The settlement agreement stipulated the Bloomfield BOE would provide $14,400 for education costs to be used until the 2019-2020 school year, would expunge the record of the plaintiff, would amend Board policies related to the expulsion of students, would define “individualized learning plan” to provided definition, would train administrators, teachers, and staff on changed policies and expelled students' rights, would provide plaintiff's counsel data about the District's progress in implementing this agreement, would acknowledge all allegations and that the District violated plaintiff's education rights, and would pay $20,000 in attorney fees.

On December 22, 2016, Hartford Board of Education settled with both plaintiffs. That settlement agreement is also sealed. This left only the plaintiffs’ claims against State defendants.

On July 16, 2018, State defendants settled with both plaintiffs. The settlement provided that the State Department of Education would provide guidance to the local education agencies about the expulsion-related provisions of Connecticut Public Act 16-147, addressing the process and timeline for district adoption of a prior expulsion hearing decision for students who transfer school districts during periods of expulsion. The State Department of Education also agreed to issue guidelines about best practices for the education the student should receive if expelled, and to circulate these guidelines to the local education agencies, boards of education and school districts at the same time, no longer than September 1, 2018. Moreover, the State Department of Education agreed to submit to the State Board of Education a proposed Board Policy Statement concerning the importance of reducing expulsions and disproportionality in expulsions, among other points, in Connecticut for consideration by the State Board no later than its December 2018 regular meeting. According to the settlement agreement, within 15 days after such time as the State Board issued a final Policy Statement, the State Department of Education should circulate it to local education agencies, boards of education and school districts.

Additionally, the State Department of Education, no later than September 1, 2018, would facilitate state oversight of alternative educational opportunities by publishing on its website, in a manner easily accessible to students and families, materials providing information for students and parents about student rights to education during periods of expulsion. These materials would also be published as part of the guidelines mentioned above, and would be sent by the State Department of Education via electronic mail to a list of agreed-upon community and legal organizations. The State Department of Education agreed to consider recommendations from the Plaintiffs' attorney in these resources, although the decision about their content would be made solely by the State Department.

The State Department of Education agreed to analyze suspension and expulsion data on an annual basis, to identify districts with meaningful disparities in the rates of these punishments and racial disparities in suspensions/expulsions. The methodology of this analysis would be determined by the State Department of Education and shared with the plaintiffs and their counsel within 30 days of the execution of the settlement agreement, whose considerations, if made within 15 days, would be taken into account before a final decision was reached.

Besides that, the State Department of Education agreed to develop a tiered monitoring and recommended remediation approach of progressive intervention generally consisting of guidance for all districts, including sharing of resources pertaining to restorative and culturally responsive practices, and, as justified by the particular circumstances it defined, more significant interventions for some districts, to be defined by the Department. Beginning in December 2020, the State Department of Education would annually determine the tiers of intervention, publish the results on its website and report the tiers annually to the State Board of Education. Beginning no later than December 2021, the State Department of Education would include in its annual reporting on the website and to the State Board of Education information concerning the progress of districts in Tier 3 toward improvement.

Finally, the State defendants agreed to pay $50,000 in fees and costs, and the plaintiffs waived any rights to apply for any additional fees and expenses in connection with all claims and potential claims resolved through the settlement agreement.

The parties agreed the Court would retain jurisdiction until March 31, 2022 to enforce the provisions of the agreement.

On July 18, 2018, Judge Stefan R. Underhill approved the settlement agreement and stipulation of dismissal. On March 31, 2022, the Court's jurisdiction expired.
original_case_data.summary_short: Two Connecticut plaintiffs are suing their respective public schools board of education and the State Board of Education for inadequate alternative education provided to expelled students. The Boards of Education and the State defendants have settled individually with the Plaintiffs. The State Department of Education agreed to develop and disclose several guidelines, as well as to implement and monitor the execution of several measures about the issues raised by the complaint.

The plaintiffs also requested reasonable attorneys' fees and costs.

On August 11, 2016, Manchester Board of Education defendants settled with one of the plaintiffs. This settlement is sealed.

On August 16, 2016, the Bloomfield Board of Education also settled with the same plaintiff. The settlement agreement stipulated the Bloomfield BOE would provide $14,400 for education costs to be used until the 2019-2020 school year, would expunge the record of the plaintiff, would amend Board policies related to the expulsion of students, would define “individualized learning plan” to provided definition, would train administrators, teachers, and staff on changed policies and expelled students' rights, would provide plaintiff's counsel data about the District's progress in implementing this agreement, would acknowledge all allegations and that the District violated plaintiff's education rights, and would pay $20,000 in attorney fees.

On December 22, 2016, Hartford Board of Education settled with both plaintiffs. That settlement agreement is also sealed. This left only the plaintiffs’ claims against State defendants.

On July 16, 2018, State defendants settled with both plaintiffs. The settlement provided that the State Department of Education would provide guidance to the local education agencies about the expulsion-related provisions of Connecticut Public Act 16-147, addressing the process and timeline for district adoption of a prior expulsion hearing decision for students who transfer school districts during periods of expulsion. The State Department of Education also agreed to issue guidelines about best practices for the education the student should receive if expelled, and to circulate these guidelines to the local education agencies, boards of education and school districts at the same time, no longer than September 1, 2018. Moreover, the State Department of Education agreed to submit to the State Board of Education a proposed Board Policy Statement concerning the importance of reducing expulsions and disproportionality in expulsions, among other points, in Connecticut for consideration by the State Board no later than its December 2018 regular meeting. According to the settlement agreement, within 15 days after such time as the State Board issued a final Policy Statement, the State Department of Education should circulate it to local education agencies, boards of education and school districts.

Additionally, the State Department of Education, no later than September 1, 2018, would facilitate state oversight of alternative educational opportunities by publishing on its website, in a manner easily accessible to students and families, materials providing information for students and parents about student rights to education during periods of expulsion. These materials would also be published as part of the guidelines mentioned above, and would be sent by the State Department of Education via electronic mail to a list of agreed-upon community and legal organizations. The State Department of Education agreed to consider recommendations from the Plaintiffs' attorney in these resources, although the decision about their content would be made solely by the State Department.

The State Department of Education agreed to analyze suspension and expulsion data on an annual basis, to identify districts with meaningful disparities in the rates of these punishments and racial disparities in suspensions/expulsions. The methodology of this analysis would be determined by the State Department of Education and shared with the plaintiffs and their counsel within 30 days of the execution of the settlement agreement, whose considerations, if made within 15 days, would be taken into account before a final decision was reached.

Besides that, the State Department of Education agreed to develop a tiered monitoring and recommended remediation approach of progressive intervention generally consisting of guidance for all districts, including sharing of resources pertaining to restorative and culturally responsive practices, and, as justified by the particular circumstances it defined, more significant interventions for some districts, to be defined by the Department. Beginning in December 2020, the State Department of Education would annually determine the tiers of intervention, publish the results on its website and report the tiers annually to the State Board of Education. Beginning no later than December 2021, the State Department of Education would include in its annual reporting on the website and to the State Board of Education information concerning the progress of districts in Tier 3 toward improvement.

Finally, the State defendants agreed to pay $50,000 in fees and costs, and the plaintiffs waived any rights to apply for any additional fees and expenses in connection with all claims and potential claims resolved through the settlement agreement.

The parties agreed the Court would retain jurisdiction until March 31, 2022 to enforce the provisions of the agreement.

On July 18, 2018, Judge Stefan R. Underhill approved the settlement agreement and stipulation of dismissal. On March 31, 2022, the Court's jurisdiction expired.

Two African-American students in Connecticut public schools initiated this lawsuit on December 15, 2015, in Connecticut Superior Court, with the case subsequently removed to the United States District Court for the District of Connecticut on January 14, 2016. The Hartford Board of Education settled with both plaintiffs on December 22, 2016, under a sealed agreement. This left only the plaintiffs’ claims against the State defendants.

On July 16, 2018, the State defendants settled with both plaintiffs. The SDE also agreed to issue and circulate guidelines on best practices for the education of expelled students to LEAs, boards of education, and school districts. Furthermore, the SDE committed to submitting a proposed Board Policy Statement to the State Board of Education concerning the importance of reducing expulsions and disproportionality in expulsions, which, once finalized by the State Board, would be circulated to LEAs, boards of education, and school districts.

Additionally, the SDE would facilitate state oversight of alternative educational opportunities by publishing easily accessible online materials for students and families detailing their rights to education during periods of expulsion. These materials would also be included in the aforementioned guidelines and disseminated via electronic mail to agreed-upon community and legal organizations. The SDE agreed to consider recommendations from the plaintiffs' attorney regarding these resources.

The SDE further committed to annually analyzing suspension and expulsion data to identify districts with meaningful disparities in punishment rates and racial disparities. The methodology for this analysis would be determined by the SDE and shared with plaintiffs and their counsel for consideration.

Moreover, the SDE agreed to develop a tiered monitoring and recommended remediation approach involving progressive intervention. This approach would generally consist of guidance for all districts, including sharing resources pertaining to restorative and culturally responsive practices, and, as justified by specific circumstances, more significant interventions for some districts. The SDE would annually determine and publish the tiers of intervention on its website, reporting these tiers annually to the State Board of Education. Annual reports would also include information concerning the progress of districts in Tier 3 toward improvement.

Finally, the State defendants agreed to pay $50,000 in fees and costs, with plaintiffs waiving rights to additional fees or expenses related to the resolved claims. The parties stipulated that the Court would retain jurisdiction until March 31, 2022, to enforce the agreement's provisions. Judge Stefan R. Underhill approved the settlement agreement and stipulation of dismissal on July 18, 2018. The Court's jurisdiction expired on March 31, 2022.

1.transformed_text:
On December 15, 2015, two African-American students in Connecticut public schools filed this lawsuit in Connecticut Superior Court. On January 14, 2016, the case was moved to the United States District Court for the District of Connecticut. The plaintiffs sued the Bloomfield Board of Education, the Manchester Board of Education, the Hartford Board of Education, the State Board of Education, and the State Department of Education under federal civil rights laws, specifically 42 U.S.C. § 1983 and Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. They claimed violations of the Connecticut Constitution, the U.S. Constitution's Equal Protection Clause (part of the Fourteenth Amendment), and Title VI.

The plaintiffs argued that after being expelled from Connecticut public schools, they did not receive proper alternative education, which denied them their basic right to an education. They claimed this problem especially affected Black students because they were expelled at a much higher rate due to how discipline policies were applied. One plaintiff brought claims against the Manchester and Bloomfield Boards of Education. Both plaintiffs brought claims against the Hartford Board of Education. The plaintiffs, represented by private lawyers and the Center for Children’s Advocacy, asked the court to declare their rights and order changes to improve the inadequate education given to expelled students. The plaintiffs also requested reasonable attorney fees and costs.

On August 11, 2016, the Manchester Board of Education settled with one of the plaintiffs. This settlement is sealed.

On August 16, 2016, the Bloomfield Board of Education also settled with the same plaintiff. Under the settlement, the Bloomfield BOE agreed to: provide $14,400 for education costs through the 2019-2020 school year; remove the expulsion from the plaintiff's record; change its policies on student expulsions; provide a definition for "individualized learning plan"; train administrators, teachers, and staff on new policies and expelled students' rights; share data with the plaintiff's lawyers about how it was meeting the agreement; admit the District had violated the plaintiff's education rights; and pay $20,000 in attorney fees.

On December 22, 2016, the Hartford Board of Education settled with both plaintiffs. That settlement agreement is also sealed. This left only the plaintiffs’ claims against State defendants.

On July 16, 2018, the State defendants settled with both plaintiffs. The settlement required the State Department of Education (SDE) to guide local school districts on the expulsion rules in Connecticut Public Act 16-147. This included details on how districts should handle expulsion decisions for students who transfer while expelled. The SDE also agreed to create and share guidelines for best practices regarding education for expelled students. These guidelines were to be sent to local education agencies, school boards, and districts by September 1, 2018. In addition, the SDE agreed to propose a policy statement to the State Board of Education by its December 2018 meeting. This statement would highlight the importance of reducing expulsions and addressing the unequal rates of expulsions in Connecticut. Once the State Board issued its final policy statement, the SDE was to distribute it to local education agencies, school boards, and districts within 15 days.

By September 1, 2018, the SDE also committed to improving state oversight of alternative education options. It would do this by publishing easy-to-access information on its website for students and families about their right to education during expulsion periods. These materials would also be included in the guidelines mentioned earlier and emailed to a list of agreed-upon community and legal groups. The SDE agreed to consider suggestions from the plaintiffs' attorney for these resources, but the SDE alone would decide the final content.

The SDE agreed to annually review suspension and expulsion data. This analysis would identify districts with significant differences in punishment rates, especially racial disparities in suspensions and expulsions. The SDE would decide how to conduct this analysis and share its plan with the plaintiffs and their lawyers within 30 days of the settlement. The SDE would consider any feedback from the plaintiffs' lawyers, if given within 15 days, before finalizing the plan.

Additionally, the SDE agreed to create a phased system for monitoring and helping districts improve. This system would involve general guidance for all districts, including sharing resources on practices that focus on repairing harm and are sensitive to different cultures. For some districts, based on specific circumstances, the SDE would define and implement more significant interventions. Starting in December 2020, the SDE would annually determine these intervention levels, publish the results online, and report them to the State Board of Education. By December 2021, the SDE would also include information in its annual online and State Board reports about how districts in the highest intervention tier (Tier 3) were improving.

Finally, the State defendants agreed to pay $50,000 in legal fees and costs. The plaintiffs, in turn, gave up their right to seek any more fees or expenses related to the claims settled in the agreement.

The parties agreed the Court would keep oversight until March 31, 2022, to ensure the agreement's terms were met.

On July 18, 2018, Judge Stefan R. Underhill approved the settlement and the agreement to dismiss the case. The Court's oversight ended on March 31, 2022.

On August 11, 2016, the Manchester school board reached an agreement with one of the students. What they agreed to is private (sealed).

A few days later, on August 16, 2016, the Bloomfield school board also settled with that same student. In their agreement, the Bloomfield school board promised to: give $14,400 for the student's education until the 2019-2020 school year; erase the expulsion from the student's school record; update its rules about expelling students; explain what an "individualized learning plan" means; teach school leaders, teachers, and staff about the new rules and the rights of expelled students; share information with the student's lawyers to show they were following the agreement; admit that the school district had violated the student's right to an education; and pay $20,000 for the student's legal fees.

On December 22, 2016, the Hartford school board settled with both students. That agreement is also private. After this, the only groups left to sue were the state education agencies.

On July 16, 2018, the State of Connecticut also reached an agreement with both students. The agreement said the State Department of Education (SDE) had to help local school districts understand and follow the rules about expulsions in a Connecticut law called Public Act 16-147. This included explaining how schools should deal with expulsion decisions for students who move to a new district while they are still expelled. The SDE also agreed to create and share a guide of the best ways to educate students who have been expelled. This guide was to be sent to all local school groups, boards, and districts by September 1, 2018. Also, the SDE agreed to suggest a new official statement to the State Board of Education by their December 2018 meeting. This statement would emphasize how important it is to have fewer expulsions and to fix the problem where some groups of students are expelled more often than others in Connecticut. Once the State Board made its final decision on this statement, the SDE had to send it out to local school groups within 15 days.

By September 1, 2018, the SDE also promised to do a better job of overseeing alternative education programs (like special schools for expelled students). They would do this by putting easy-to-find information on their website for students and families about their right to an education even when they are expelled. These materials would also be part of the guide mentioned before and sent by email to specific community and legal groups. The SDE said they would listen to ideas from the students' lawyer for these materials, but the SDE would make the final decisions on what they said.

The SDE agreed to look at information (data) about student suspensions and expulsions every year. This check would help them find school districts where there were big differences in how often students were disciplined, especially if Black students or other racial groups were suspended or expelled much more often. The SDE would decide how to do this check and share their plan with the students and their lawyers within 30 days of the agreement. They would consider any ideas from the students' lawyers, if given within 15 days, before making the plan final.

Also, the SDE agreed to create a step-by-step system to check on schools and help them get better. This system would give general advice to all school districts, including sharing ideas about how to fix problems in a way that helps everyone involved and respects different cultures. For some districts, depending on their specific situations, the SDE would step in with more serious help or changes. Starting in December 2020, the SDE would decide these levels of help every year, share the results online, and tell the State Board of Education. By December 2021, the SDE would also include updates in their yearly online and State Board reports about how districts needing the most help (Tier 3) were getting better.

Finally, the state groups agreed to pay $50,000 for the students' legal fees and other costs. In return, the students agreed not to ask for any more money for legal fees or costs related to the issues they settled.

Everyone involved agreed that the court would keep an eye on things until March 31, 2022, to make sure the agreement was followed. On July 18, 2018, Judge Stefan R. Underhill approved the agreement and closed the case. The court's role in overseeing the agreement ended on March 31, 2022.

0.text:
On December 15, 2015, two African-American students in Connecticut public schools filed this lawsuit in Connecticut Superior Court. On January 14, 2016, the case was removed to the United States District Court for the District of Connecticut. The plaintiffs sued the Bloomfield Board of Education, the Manchester Board of Education, the Hartford Board of Education, the State Board of Education, and the State Department of Education under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 and Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, alleging violations of the Constitution of Connecticut, the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, and Title VI.

Specifically, the plaintiffs claimed that, after their expulsion from Connecticut public schools, they were given inadequate alternative education, thus depriving them of their fundamental right to an education. They argued that Black students were particularly affected by these inadequacies because Black students were disproportionately expelled as a result of selective enforcement of neutral discipline policies. One plaintiff brought claims against the Manchester and Bloomfield Boards of Education. Both plaintiffs brought claims against the Hartford Board of Education. The plaintiffs, represented by private counsel and the Center for Children’s Advocacy, asked the court for declaratory and injunctive relief to improve the insufficient education provided to students who had been expelled. The plaintiffs also requested reasonable attorneys' fees and costs.

On August 11, 2016, Manchester Board of Education defendants settled with one of the plaintiffs. This settlement is sealed.

On August 16, 2016, the Bloomfield Board of Education also settled with the same plaintiff. The settlement agreement stipulated the Bloomfield BOE would provide $14,400 for education costs to be used until the 2019-2020 school year, would expunge the record of the plaintiff, would amend Board policies related to the expulsion of students, would define “individualized learning plan” to provided definition, would train administrators, teachers, and staff on changed policies and expelled students' rights, would provide plaintiff's counsel data about the District's progress in implementing this agreement, would acknowledge all allegations and that the District violated plaintiff's education rights, and would pay $20,000 in attorney fees.

On December 22, 2016, Hartford Board of Education settled with both plaintiffs. That settlement agreement is also sealed. This left only the plaintiffs’ claims against State defendants.

On July 16, 2018, State defendants settled with both plaintiffs. The settlement provided that the State Department of Education would provide guidance to the local education agencies about the expulsion-related provisions of Connecticut Public Act 16-147, addressing the process and timeline for district adoption of a prior expulsion hearing decision for students who transfer school districts during periods of expulsion. The State Department of Education also agreed to issue guidelines about best practices for the education the student should receive if expelled, and to circulate these guidelines to the local education agencies, boards of education and school districts at the same time, no longer than September 1, 2018. Moreover, the State Department of Education agreed to submit to the State Board of Education a proposed Board Policy Statement concerning the importance of reducing expulsions and disproportionality in expulsions, among other points, in Connecticut for consideration by the State Board no later than its December 2018 regular meeting. According to the settlement agreement, within 15 days after such time as the State Board issued a final Policy Statement, the State Department of Education should circulate it to local education agencies, boards of education and school districts.

Additionally, the State Department of Education, no later than September 1, 2018, would facilitate state oversight of alternative educational opportunities by publishing on its website, in a manner easily accessible to students and families, materials providing information for students and parents about student rights to education during periods of expulsion. These materials would also be published as part of the guidelines mentioned above, and would be sent by the State Department of Education via electronic mail to a list of agreed-upon community and legal organizations. The State Department of Education agreed to consider recommendations from the Plaintiffs' attorney in these resources, although the decision about their content would be made solely by the State Department.

The State Department of Education agreed to analyze suspension and expulsion data on an annual basis, to identify districts with meaningful disparities in the rates of these punishments and racial disparities in suspensions/expulsions. The methodology of this analysis would be determined by the State Department of Education and shared with the plaintiffs and their counsel within 30 days of the execution of the settlement agreement, whose considerations, if made within 15 days, would be taken into account before a final decision was reached.

Besides that, the State Department of Education agreed to develop a tiered monitoring and recommended remediation approach of progressive intervention generally consisting of guidance for all districts, including sharing of resources pertaining to restorative and culturally responsive practices, and, as justified by the particular circumstances it defined, more significant interventions for some districts, to be defined by the Department. Beginning in December 2020, the State Department of Education would annually determine the tiers of intervention, publish the results on its website and report the tiers annually to the State Board of Education. Beginning no later than December 2021, the State Department of Education would include in its annual reporting on the website and to the State Board of Education information concerning the progress of districts in Tier 3 toward improvement.

Finally, the State defendants agreed to pay $50,000 in fees and costs, and the plaintiffs waived any rights to apply for any additional fees and expenses in connection with all claims and potential claims resolved through the settlement agreement.

The parties agreed the Court would retain jurisdiction until March 31, 2022 to enforce the provisions of the agreement.

On July 18, 2018, Judge Stefan R. Underhill approved the settlement agreement and stipulation of dismissal. On March 31, 2022, the Court's jurisdiction expired.

1.transformed_text:
In December 2015, two African-American students in Connecticut initiated a legal challenge, seeking to rectify what they viewed as a systemic failure in the state's educational system. Their lawsuit, initially filed in state court but soon moved to the federal arena, targeted multiple entities—the Bloomfield, Manchester, and Hartford Boards of Education, alongside the State Board of Education and the State Department of Education. They brought claims under federal civil rights laws and the state constitution, asserting that their fundamental right to an education had been violated.

At the heart of their complaint was the assertion that after being expelled from public schools, they were relegated to inadequate alternative education, effectively denying them their fundamental right to learn. Crucially, they contended that this issue disproportionately harmed Black students, who, they argued, faced selective enforcement of discipline policies leading to higher expulsion rates. With the support of private counsel and the Center for Children’s Advocacy, the students sought not just acknowledgment of these wrongs, but also court-ordered changes to improve the educational provisions for all expelled students, alongside compensation for their legal expenses.

As the litigation progressed, the local school boards began to address the students' concerns through settlements. In August 2016, the Manchester and Bloomfield Boards of Education reached agreements with one of the plaintiffs. The Bloomfield settlement, in particular, offered a clear path forward: it provided funds for the student's education, expunged their disciplinary record, and committed the Board to revise its expulsion policies, define individualized learning plans, and train staff on new procedures and student rights, acknowledging past violations. By December 2016, the Hartford Board of Education also settled with both students, leaving only the broader claims against the state-level defendants to be resolved.

The most significant resolution came in July 2018, when the State defendants agreed to a comprehensive settlement with both plaintiffs. This agreement reflected the students' broader ambition to effect systemic change across Connecticut. The State Department of Education committed to a series of initiatives designed to improve the educational landscape for expelled students statewide. These included providing clear guidance to local agencies on expulsion policies, issuing best practice guidelines for alternative education, and proposing a statewide policy statement to the State Board of Education emphasizing the reduction of expulsions and racial disparities. Further, the state agreed to enhance oversight by publishing accessible information for students and families about their educational rights during expulsion, and crucially, to annually analyze suspension and expulsion data to identify districts with significant disparities. This data-driven approach would inform a tiered system of intervention, ranging from general guidance to more targeted support for districts needing improvement, with progress reported publicly and to the State Board of Education. These measures aimed to ensure that the issues raised by the students would be addressed on a statewide, ongoing basis.

As part of this landmark agreement, the State also agreed to cover a portion of the plaintiffs' legal fees and costs. To ensure the ambitious terms of the settlement were indeed carried out, the court wisely retained jurisdiction over the case until March 2022, allowing it to oversee the implementation of these far-reaching policy changes. With the court's approval of the settlement in July 2018, this significant chapter in Connecticut's educational history came to a close, its impact continuing to unfold as the agreed-upon reforms took root.

Imagine two young students in Connecticut, both African-American, whose lives were thrown off course when they were told they could no longer attend their regular schools. They found themselves without proper education, a situation that seemed to hit Black students harder than others due to unfair rules about student behavior.

The State also pledged to keep a close eye on things. They would make it easy for families to find information about their children's learning rights during these difficult times. Crucially, they would regularly look at numbers about student dismissals to spot schools where unfair patterns appeared. This information would guide a system of support, from general advice to more focused help for schools that needed to improve, with progress shared openly. original_case_data.name: Inmates of Judge John J. Connelly Youth Center v. Dukakis
settlement_agreement: Court Approved Settlement or Consent Decree
original_case_data.summary:
In 1975, juveniles in custody of the Department of Youth Services (DYS) at the Judge J. Connelly Youth Center (Roslindale) filed a class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts against the Governor of Massachusetts. The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief from allegedly unconstitutional conditions at Roslindale. The Juvenile Court Advocacy Program, and the Massachusetts Defenders Committee represented the plaintiffs.

After pretrial conferences, the parties entered into a Consent Decree. On April 2, 1976, the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts (Judge Wendell Arthur Garrity, Jr.) ordered a Consent Decree as binding judgment in the case.

The Consent Decree provided that: DYS would stop commingling pretrial detainees with committed juveniles awaiting placement; parents would be notified as soon as a juvenile entered the Roslindale for detention, and the attorney for detainee would be determined; detainees could send and receive mail to and from any person, and parcels could only be opened in the presence of the addressee to check for contraband; Roslindale would furnish all items necessary to write and send letters, including postage for seven first class letters per week; twice a week, two-hour visitation periods would be available for parents and guardians; attorneys and clergy could visit at any time between 9:00 A.M. and 7:00 P.M. seven days a week; local telephone calls of five-minute duration would be available six days a week; current and future employees would be screened for emotional fitness to work with children in a custodial setting; each detainee would be assigned a counselor to assist them with any problems arising from detention, and for each 45 detainees there would be a counseling supervisor; all employees were to undergo regular in-service training; individual education needs would be met for each detainee, with class sizes not to exceed 12 detainees; each detainee would be examined by a doctor or registered nurse with 24 hours of admission to Roslindale, and at least every four months afterwards; psychiatric and emergency medical treatment would be made available to each detainee; each detainee was to have at least 75 square feet of personal space, and there was to be a common room per each 20 detainees; upon admission, each detainee would receive a clean room, and be responsible for cleaning up after that; each student would receive a minimum of two hours outdoor recreation on school days, and four hours on non-school days; games, books, and periodicals would be provided to detainees; mandatory sleeping hours would not exceed 8 hours per night; new detainees would be provided with clean mattresses and bedding, as well as towels, toothbrushes and toothpaste; bedding would be cleaned weekly; daily showers or baths would be available to all detainees, with towels changed twice weekly; breakfast and an evening meal would be provided to all detainees, with an snack available after the evening meal, if served before 5:00 P.M.; corporal punishment was strictly forbidden; permitted and proscribed behavior was to be made clear to all detainees upon admission to Roslindale; and any restriction of rights due to behavior must arise from written rules available to detainees, and a hearing must be held on the matter as soon as possible.

The defendants had 8 months to bring Roslindale within full compliance of the Consent Decree, or be subject to closure. Five persons were appointed to a Monitoring Board for 2 years which would submit findings and recommendations to both parties bi-monthly for the first 8 months, and quarterly after that. The Court (Judge Garrity) retained jurisdiction over the matter. There is no docket or further information about the disposition of the case.

1.transformed_text:
In 1975, juveniles in custody of the Department of Youth Services (DYS) at the Judge J. Connelly Youth Center (Roslindale) filed a class action in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts against the Governor of Massachusetts, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief for allegedly unconstitutional conditions at Roslindale. The plaintiffs were represented by the Juvenile Court Advocacy Program and the Massachusetts Defenders Committee.

Following pretrial conferences, the parties entered into a Consent Decree, which the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts (Judge Wendell Arthur Garrity, Jr.) ordered as binding judgment on April 2, 1976.

The Consent Decree outlined comprehensive reforms across several key areas. It mandated an end to the commingling of pretrial detainees with committed juveniles awaiting placement. Communication and access provisions included immediate parental notification upon a juvenile's admission and determination of legal representation. Detainees were granted rights regarding mail, including provision of postage for seven first-class letters weekly, and parcels opened in their presence. Structured visitation periods were established for parents and guardians, while attorneys and clergy had broad access. Local telephone calls of five-minute duration were available six days a week.

Staffing requirements included screening current and future employees for emotional fitness, assigning individual counselors to detainees (with a counseling supervisor for every 45 detainees), and ensuring all employees underwent regular in-service training. Educational needs were to be met individually, with class sizes not exceeding 12 detainees. Medical care provisions included initial examinations by a doctor or registered nurse within 24 hours of admission and at least every four months thereafter, alongside access to psychiatric and emergency medical treatment.

Living conditions were significantly addressed, detailing minimum personal space of 75 square feet per detainee and a common room for every 20 detainees. Standards for cleanliness included a clean room upon admission, provision of clean mattresses, bedding, towels, toothbrushes, and toothpaste, with weekly bedding changes and twice-weekly towel changes. Detainees were guaranteed daily showers or baths, and provision of breakfast, an evening meal, and a snack. Specific outdoor recreation hours were mandated (minimum two hours on school days, four hours on non-school days), and access to games, books, and periodicals was required, with mandatory sleeping hours not exceeding 8 hours per night.

Furthermore, the Decree strictly prohibited corporal punishment. It required clear communication of permitted and proscribed behavior to all detainees upon admission, stipulating that any restriction of rights due to behavior must arise from written rules available to detainees, and a hearing must be held on the matter as soon as possible.

Connelly Youth Center (Roslindale). The suit, brought against the Governor of Massachusetts, sought declaratory and injunctive relief concerning allegedly unconstitutional conditions at Roslindale.
