3.transformed_text:
In 1975, young people who were staying at a place called the Judge J. Connelly Youth Center (or Roslindale for short), run by the Department of Youth Services (DYS), started a special kind of lawsuit called a "class action" in a federal court in Massachusetts. Think of a class action like a group of students all having the same problem with a school rule, so one student speaks up for everyone. In this case, it was a lawsuit filed for a whole group of young people who had similar complaints. They sued the Governor, saying that the conditions at Roslindale were so bad they actually went against their basic rights, which are protected by the U.S. Constitution. They asked the court to make the state fix these problems. Two groups, the Juvenile Court Advocacy Program and the Massachusetts Defenders Committee, helped these young people with their case.

After a lot of talks before the actual trial started, both sides agreed to something called a "Consent Decree." This is like a written agreement, approved by the judge, that both sides promise to stick to. On April 2, 1976, the federal court in Massachusetts, with Judge Wendell Arthur Garrity, Jr. in charge, officially approved this Consent Decree. This meant it was a final decision that everyone had to follow.

The Consent Decree laid out many rules: The DYS had to stop putting young people who were just waiting for their court date in the same living areas as those who had already been sentenced and were waiting to be moved to a different, more permanent place. Parents would be told right away when a young person was brought to Roslindale, and that young person would get a lawyer. Young people could send and receive mail freely, and packages could only be opened in front of them, just to check for things that weren't allowed. Roslindale would give them everything they needed to write and send letters, including stamps for seven regular letters each week. Parents and guardians could visit twice a week for two hours each time. Lawyers and religious leaders could visit any day, from 9:00 AM to 7:00 PM. They could make local phone calls, five minutes long, six days a week. All staff, new and old, had to be checked to make sure they were emotionally fit to work with kids in a detention center. Each young person would get a counselor to help them with problems from being held there, and for every 45 young people, there would be a supervisor for the counselors. All employees would get regular training. Each young person's education needs would be met, with no more than 12 students in a class. Every young person would see a doctor or nurse within 24 hours of arriving at Roslindale, and at least every four months after that. Mental health care and emergency medical help would be available to every young person. Each young person would have at least 75 square feet of their own space (about the size of a small bedroom). There would also be one common room for every 20 young people. When they arrived, each young person would get a clean room and be responsible for keeping it clean afterward. Each young person would get at least two hours of outdoor time on school days and four hours on days they didn't have school. Games, books, and magazines would be provided. They wouldn't be forced to sleep more than 8 hours per night. New young people would get clean mattresses, sheets, blankets, towels, toothbrushes, and toothpaste. Bedding would be cleaned weekly. All young people could take daily showers or baths, and towels would be changed twice a week. Breakfast and an evening meal would be provided. If the evening meal was served before 5:00 PM, a snack would be available afterward. Physical punishment was strictly forbidden. Rules about what behavior was allowed and not allowed would be clearly explained to all young people when they arrived. And if their rights were limited because of their behavior, it had to be based on written rules given to them, and they had to have a hearing about it as soon as possible.

The state officials had eight months to make sure Roslindale fully followed the agreement. If they didn't, the facility could be shut down. A special group of five people, called a Monitoring Board, was put in place for two years. This board would report what they found and their suggestions to both sides every two months for the first eight months, and then every three months after that. The court, with Judge Garrity still in charge, kept the power to make sure the agreement was being followed. There's no public record or more information about how the case finally ended.

Communication with the outside world was to be protected, allowing detainees to send and receive mail freely, with parcels opened only in the addressee's presence for contraband checks. The court's resolution, embodied in the Consent Decree, directly addressed the problematic conditions. It required the Department of Youth Services (DYS) to cease housing pretrial detainees with committed juveniles, ensuring proper segregation. Communication with the outside world was safeguarded, guaranteeing prompt parental notification and legal representation upon entry, free mail exchange (with parcels opened only in the addressee's presence for contraband checks), provision of writing materials and postage for seven weekly first-class letters, expanded two-hour visitation periods for parents and guardians twice a week, and unrestricted attorney and clergy visits from 9:00 A.M. to 7:00 P.M. daily. Local five-minute phone calls were also to be available six days a week.

Focusing on the juveniles' well-being, the decree mandated emotional fitness screening for all DYS employees, assigned a dedicated counselor to each detainee with a supervisor for every 45, and required regular staff training. Educational needs were to be met individually, with class sizes capped at 12. Health provisions were stringent, requiring medical examinations within 24 hours of admission and every four months thereafter, along with access to psychiatric and emergency medical treatment. Living conditions were improved, requiring at least 75 square feet of personal space per detainee, a common room for every 20, and clean rooms upon admission. Recreation was prioritized with a minimum of two hours outdoor activity on school days and four hours on non-school days, plus access to games, books, and periodicals. Sleeping hours were capped at 8 hours per night. Basic hygiene was ensured through clean mattresses, bedding, towels, toothbrushes, and toothpaste upon admission, weekly bedding changes, and daily showers or baths with twice-weekly towel changes. Nutritional needs included breakfast, an evening meal, and a snack if the evening meal was served before 5:00 P.M. Finally, corporal punishment was strictly forbidden, and any restriction of rights due to behavior required written rules and a prompt hearing.

To ensure these reforms were implemented, the court's order stipulated an 8-month deadline for full compliance, with the threat of closure for failure. A five-person Monitoring Board was also established for two years to provide regular oversight and recommendations, and the Court retained jurisdiction to enforce the decree, underscoring its commitment to sustained improvement.
